user_input: What are some notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['The place was fully 
renovated in 1995 and in 
2003. It is considered one 
of the top luxury hotels in 
Greece. It is also the regular 
choice of stay for the prime 
minister and ministers while 
attending the Thessaloniki 
International Trade Fair; among 
its clientele are also many 
Greek and foreign personalities 
(politicians, artists etc). 
1.3  Umbrellas.
This emblematic sculpture 
(height: 13 m.) created by the 
significant Greek visual artist 
George Zongolopoulos, was 
fitted in place in 1997; another 
of his sculptures by the same 
title is decorating the entrance 
to the Macedonian Museum 
of Contemporary Art, (see p. 
31). In 1993 this piece of art 
represented Greece in the 
Venice Biennale. It is one of the 
newest and most photographed 
monuments of the city.
1.4  Agioi Kyrillos and 
Methodios [Saints Cyril and 
Methodius] Church.
This imposing church (on 
Megalou Alexandrou Ave.) is 
among the city’s newest and is 
dedicated to the two brothers 
who contributed decisively in 
bringing Christianity to the 
Slavs in the 9th c. and devised 
a new type of writing in the 
Slavic language. A well-tended 
garden surrounds the church. 
55
56', '13
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia. 
Fine depictions of the Ascension 
of Christ, the Prophets and the 
Divine Liturgy decorate the dome.
6 	ROTUNDA [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its 
4. 
The church of the 
Transfiguration 
of the Saviour.
5. 
The impressive 
Rotunda 
monument 
(Agios Georgios).
6.', 'It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque. It was destroyed 
in 1917 by the fire but it was 
restored and reopened in 
1948. It is a five-aisle transept 
basilica with a women’s gallery 
and a narthex. The sculpted 
decorative motifs originate 
from the 5th c. basilica and 
other buildings and this 
explains their variety; equally 
interesting are the capitals (5th 
and 6th c.). The mosaics found 
on the west side date to the 
5th c. while those on the piers 
around the sanctuary [bema] 
are later additions. Those 
depicting the saint among 
children, flanked by the bishop 
and the prefect are of great 
value. In the basement lies the 
Krypt on the site where Roman 
public baths used to be. This 
is the place of martyrdom for 
Saint Demetrius in 303 or 305. 
When the 5th c. Church was 
built, the baths became a place 
of special worship and the water 
flowing was believed to be holy. 
Since 1988 it is an exhibition 
area for sculptures, capitals, 
panels, vessels etc, where 
cultural events also take place.
6']
reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki is rich in Byzantine heritage, offering several notable monuments that are perfect for sightseeing and capturing Instagrammable moments. Here are some key sites to explore:

1. **Agios Dimitrios Church**: This is the most famous Byzantine church in Thessaloniki, dedicated to the city's patron saint, St. Demetrius. Built in the 7th century on the ruins of a 5th-century basilica, it features stunning mosaics and a significant crypt where St. Demetrius was martyred. The church's impressive architecture and historical significance make it a must-visit.

2. **Rotunda**: Originally constructed as a mausoleum for Emperor Galerius in 306 AD, the Rotunda is an architectural marvel with a massive dome. It has served various purposes over the centuries, including a church and a mosque. The preserved mosaics from the 5th century are particularly noteworthy, showcasing intricate designs and vibrant colors.

3. **Holy Twelve Apostles Church**: Built between 1310 and 1314, this church is one of the oldest in the city. It was part of a monastery dedicated to the Virgin Mary and features beautiful murals depicting her life. The church's serene atmosphere and historical context make it a peaceful spot for reflection.

4. **Agios Panteleimonas Church**: Located near the Rotunda, this church is believed to have been the main church of the Monastery of Kyr Isaac. Its unique architecture and historical murals, which date back to the 13th and 14th centuries, provide insight into the Byzantine era.

5. **The Byzantine Walls**: While not a single monument, the remnants of the Byzantine walls surrounding Thessaloniki offer stunning views of the city and the sea. Walking along these ancient fortifications is a great way to appreciate the city's history.

These sites not only reflect Thessaloniki's rich Byzantine past but also provide excellent opportunities for photography and local interaction, making them ideal for a weekend visit.
reference: Thessaloniki is home to several notable Byzantine monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which was built between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. These monuments are recognized for their architectural significance and were declared UNESCO World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

response:
Byzantine church-building refers to the architectural style and construction techniques used during the Byzantine Empire, particularly from the 4th to the 15th centuries. This style is characterized by its grand domes, intricate mosaics, and cross-in-square layouts, which were designed to create a sense of heavenly space and reflect the glory of God. In Thessaloniki, this architectural tradition is particularly significant due to the city's historical role as a major center of Christianity and culture during the Byzantine period.

Thessaloniki was the second most important city of the Byzantine Empire after Constantinople, and it became a hub for early Christian architecture. The city is home to numerous Byzantine monuments, many of which have been designated as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. These include churches like Agios Dimitrios, the patron saint of Thessaloniki, and the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, showcasing the evolution of Byzantine art and architecture.

The importance of Byzantine church-building in Thessaloniki lies not only in its aesthetic and architectural value but also in its cultural and historical significance. These churches served as places of worship, community gathering, and artistic expression, influencing the development of Christian architecture throughout the region. They reflect the city's rich history and its role in the spread of Christianity, making them essential for understanding the cultural heritage of Greece.

For a solo traveler interested in sightseeing, exploring these Byzantine churches offers a unique opportunity to connect with the local culture and history. Many of these sites are also Instagrammable spots, providing picturesque backdrops for photography. Engaging with the local community around these monuments can enhance your experience, allowing for meaningful interactions and a deeper appreciation of Thessaloniki's Byzantine legacy.
reference: Byzantine church-building refers to the construction of Christian monuments and churches during the Byzantine period, particularly in Thessaloniki, which was the second most important city of the empire after Constantinople. This period, spanning from the 4th to the 15th century, saw the creation of significant Christian monuments that have a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. These monuments are recognized for their architectural and artistic value, leading UNESCO to declare them World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

['8
 315 BC:	
26 adjoining townlets 
merge to form Thessaloniki. 
The town is founded by 
Cassander, King of Macedonia, 
and named after his wife 
Thessaloniki – half sister  
to Alexander the Great.
 168 BC:	
The Romans take the city 
over.
 148 BC:	
It becomes the capital  
town of the roman province 
of Macedonia.
 130 BC:	
Construction of Via Egnatia 
which connected the town 
with the then known world.
 circa 50 BC:	
Cicero, the Roman orator 
becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians.', '• Middle Byzantine 
period (8th – 12th c.). It 
includes the chapters: i) From 
Iconomachy to the splendour 
of the Macedonian and the 
Komnenian Dynasties (room 4) 
where the art and culture of 
the middle Byzantine period 
is shown, ii) Dynasties of the 
Byzantine emperors (room 
5) where visitors can use 
learning resources to explore 
the imperial dynasties from 
emperor Heraclius (610 – 641) 
until the Palaiologan Dynasty 
(1261 – 1453) and iii) The 
Byzantine Castle (room 6) 
dealing with the creation and 
structuring of a castle in those 
times.
• Late Byzantine period 
(1204-1453). The chapter 
The twilight of Byzantium 
(room 7) describes the last 
centuries of the empire i.e.  
the period between 1204 
when Constantinople was 
seized by the Crusaders and 
1453 when it was conquered 
by the Ottoman Turks.
• Post Byzantine period 
(1453 – 19th c.). A chapter 
titled Byzantium after 
Byzantium –Byzantine legacy 
in the years that followed the 
Conquest unfolds in room 10.
• Private collections.', '10

Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to

to be a katholicon [main church]

on the aisle with images of

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

THESSALONIKI', '9
T H E S S A LO N I K I
settles in town, chased out  
of European countries – 
mostly of the Iberian pninsula. 
Their role in Thessaloniki’s 
history will be a significant 
one until the mid-20th century.
 16th-18th c.:	
Thessaloniki grows,  
and the various ethnic and 
religious communities live  
in harmony. In the 18th c.  
the town acquires the features  
of a large trade centre.
 Late 19th c.:	
A railway connection is 
established with Europe and 
Constantinople. Infrastructure 
gets streamlined and 
Thessaloniki acquires the feel 
of a cosmopolitan European 
city. The Greeks become at 
this point in time the largest 
part of the population.
 1890:	
Fire incinerates a considerable

zone.
 1912:	
During the 1st Balkan War, 
the Greek army seizes the 
town on October 26th; after 
five centuries of ottoman 
occupation, Thessaloniki 
becomes part of Greece.
 1916:	
Following a clash with 
King Constantine, Eleftherios 
Venizelos forms the 
temporary “National Defence 
Government” in Thessaloniki, 
which remained there for 
several months.
 1917:	
The biggest part of the 
town is destroyed by a fire 
that breaks out on August 
18th and lasts for 32 hours.']

response:
Constantinople, known today as Istanbul, served as the capital of the Byzantine Empire and was a pivotal center of political, cultural, and economic life from its founding in 330 AD until the fall of the empire in 1453. Established by Emperor Constantine the Great, the city was strategically located on the Bosporus Strait, making it a crucial hub for trade and military defense between Europe and Asia.

As the capital, Constantinople was the seat of the emperor and the administrative heart of the empire. It housed the imperial court, government institutions, and the Orthodox Church, which played a significant role in the empire's identity and governance. The city was renowned for its architectural marvels, including the Hagia Sophia, which symbolized the glory of Byzantine architecture and Christian faith.

Culturally, Constantinople was a melting pot of influences, blending Greek, Roman, and Eastern traditions. This cultural richness fostered advancements in art, literature, and philosophy, making the city a beacon of learning and creativity during the Middle Ages. The Byzantine Empire's legal and administrative systems, codified under Justinian I, were also centered in Constantinople, influencing governance in many regions.

Economically, Constantinople thrived due to its strategic location along trade routes, facilitating commerce between Europe, Asia, and Africa. The city's wealth attracted merchants and artisans, contributing to its cosmopolitan atmosphere.

Moreover, Constantinople's fortifications, including the famous walls, provided protection against invasions, allowing the empire to endure for centuries. The city's fall to the Ottoman Turks in 1453 marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, but its legacy continues to influence modern culture and history.

In summary, Constantinople was not only the political and administrative capital of the Byzantine Empire but also a cultural and economic powerhouse that shaped the course of history in the region.
reference: Constantinople was the most important city of the Byzantine Empire, serving as its capital and co-reigning city during the Byzantine period.

reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. response:
The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, located in Thessaloniki, is one of the city's oldest and most significant Byzantine churches. Built between 1310 and 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I, it originally served as the katholicon (main church) of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God). The church is renowned for its exquisite architecture and rich iconography, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in Byzantine art and history.

The church features a cross-in-square design, typical of Byzantine architecture, and is adorned with stunning murals that depict scenes from the life of the Holy Virgin. These artworks not only showcase the artistic skills of the period but also reflect the religious devotion of the community at the time. The mural of Theotokos and the Founder is particularly noteworthy, illustrating the church's historical significance and its connection to the Orthodox faith.

In 1988, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church was recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage Monument, highlighting its importance within the broader context of Byzantine heritage. This designation underscores the church's role in the cultural and religious landscape of Thessaloniki, which was a major center of Christianity during the Byzantine era.

Visiting the Holy Twelve Apostles Church offers a unique opportunity to experience the spiritual atmosphere of a site that has stood for over seven centuries. Its location in the heart of Thessaloniki makes it easily accessible for sightseeing, and its historical significance provides a rich narrative that enhances the visitor experience. The church is not only an architectural gem but also a testament to the city's enduring legacy as a center of Christian faith and Byzantine culture.
reference: The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki, built between 1310 and 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God), which is evident from the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as the iconography on the aisle illustrating the life of the Holy Virgin. The church is part of the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, which were recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments in 1988 due to their exceptional representation of Byzantine church-building and art. This makes a visit to the Holy Twelve Apostles Church a significant experience for those interested in the history and architecture of the Byzantine period.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street holds historical significance as it is a remnant of the ancient Roman road network, specifically constructed in the 2nd century BC. This road connected Dyrrhachium, known today as Durrës in Albania, to Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). The route was vital for trade and military movements, facilitating cultural and economic exchanges between the regions.

The connection to Albania is particularly noteworthy because Dyrrhachium was a key port city in the Roman Empire, serving as a gateway for goods and people traveling between the Adriatic Sea and the eastern Mediterranean. This strategic importance contributed to the development of Thessaloniki as a major urban center in the region.

Egnatia Street itself has evolved over the centuries, transitioning from a Roman thoroughfare to a bustling modern avenue. It splits the historic center of Thessaloniki, showcasing a blend of architectural styles, including eclectic and art deco buildings from the early 20th century. The street is not only a commercial hub but also a cultural artery, lined with significant monuments and sites that reflect the city’s rich history.

For a first-time visitor, exploring Egnatia Street offers a glimpse into the historical ties between Greece and Albania, as well as the broader narrative of the Roman Empire's influence in the region. The street's vibrant atmosphere, combined with its historical context, makes it an ideal spot for sightseeing and capturing Instagrammable moments, while also providing opportunities to engage with local culture and history.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it was part of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
The Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.) grounds are a vibrant hub of activity and culture in the city, making them an excellent spot for a weekend visit. Established in 1926, T.I.F. is the premier trade fair in the Balkans, held every September, showcasing the achievements of Greek industry and entrepreneurship. The fairgrounds host numerous exhibitions throughout the year, attracting over 2 million visitors annually.

Surrounding the T.I.F. grounds, you’ll find several notable attractions. The Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, established in 1979, is a must-see. It features modern sculptures and historical artifacts, providing a glimpse into Greece's artistic evolution. The museum's courtyard, with its striking installations, offers great photo opportunities for your Instagram feed.

For those interested in cultural events, the T.I.F. grounds also house two modern convention centers: Ioannis Vellidis and Nikolaos Germanos, which host various events throughout the year. The area is well-connected, with multiple access points via Angelaki and Egnatia streets, making it easy to explore.

Nearby, you can enjoy the bustling atmosphere of Aristotelous Square, a central gathering place lined with cafes and shops. This square is perfect for people-watching and immersing yourself in local life. Additionally, the vibrant nightlife of Kalamaria and Peraia is just a short distance away, offering a range of dining and entertainment options.

If you’re looking for artistic performances, consider visiting the nearby theatres, such as the Vasiliko Theatre and the Theatre of the Society for Macedonian Studies, which host various shows throughout the summer.

Overall, the T.I.F. grounds and their surroundings provide a rich blend of culture, art, and local experiences, making them an ideal destination for your leisure trip to Thessaloniki.
reference: The TIF grounds are located at the end of Egnatia Street, which is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been there since the city's founding. This area is part of a busy shopping district filled with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Nearby, you can find Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés, bars, and restaurants, as well as the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations and will soon house an exhibition of finds from metro excavations.

response:
Thessaloniki, a city rich in history and culture, offers several fascinating places to explore:

1. **White Tower**: This iconic monument, originally known as the Tower of the Janissaries, served as a prison and fortification. Painted white in 1890, it now houses exhibitions on Thessaloniki's history. Climb to the top for stunning views of the Thermaic Gulf and the city.

2. **Rotunda**: Built in the 4th century as a mausoleum for Emperor Galerius, this massive structure has served various purposes over the centuries, including a church and mosque. Its impressive mosaics and architecture reflect the city's diverse cultural heritage.

3. **Aristotelous Square**: The city's main square, designed in the 19th century, is a vibrant hub surrounded by cafes and shops. It offers a perfect spot for people-watching and enjoying the local atmosphere.

4. **Ano Poli (Upper Town)**: This historic district features traditional architecture, narrow streets, and stunning views of the city. Explore the Byzantine walls and visit the Vlatadon Monastery, which dates back to the 14th century.

5. **Byzantine Walls**: These ancient fortifications offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's past. Walking along the walls provides panoramic views and a sense of the city's historical significance.

6. **Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki**: This museum showcases the rich Sephardic heritage of the city, which dates back to the 15th century. It highlights the contributions of the Jewish community to Thessaloniki's cultural landscape.

7. **Ladadika District**: Known for its vibrant nightlife and dining options, this area is filled with colorful buildings and traditional tavernas. It's an excellent place to experience local cuisine and meet locals.

These sites not only offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's multifaceted history but also provide numerous opportunities for memorable photographs and interactions with the local culture. Enjoy your weekend exploring this captivating city!
reference: In Thessaloniki, one must visit Egnatia Street, a central avenue that has existed since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Another highlight is Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, where you can find the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants. Additionally, the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, is notable for being the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds. Nearby is the City Manor, known as Karavan Serai, which served as the Town Hall until recently.

BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. response:
Egnatia Street holds significant historical importance as it was part of the ancient Roman road network, specifically constructed in the 2nd century BC. This road connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) to Constantinople, which was then known as Byzantium and later became the capital of the Byzantine Empire. The construction of Egnatia Street facilitated trade and military movement across the region, linking Thessaloniki to key cities and enhancing its role as a vital hub in the Roman Empire.

As Thessaloniki evolved, Egnatia Street remained central to the city’s development, serving as a major thoroughfare that split the historic center. It became a bustling area filled with shops, hotels, and important monuments, reflecting the city’s multicultural heritage influenced by various empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman. The street's historical significance is further underscored by its connection to Constantinople, which was a center of power, culture, and commerce for centuries.

The proximity of Egnatia Street to significant landmarks, such as the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki and Kolomvou Square, highlights its ongoing relevance in contemporary urban life. Today, it remains a vibrant area where visitors can experience the rich history of Thessaloniki while enjoying modern amenities. The historical context of Egnatia Street not only enriches the visitor experience but also provides insight into the city’s evolution and its enduring connection to Constantinople, making it a must-see for anyone interested in the historical tapestry of the region.
reference: Egnatia Street is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, which connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople, highlighting its historical significance as a vital route in ancient times.

Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next

that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the

covered by a large rectangular

part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public

DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum 
Thermae.
Polygonal building.', '29
3rd walk:

MUSEUM AREA
8 	\x07PALACE OF GALERIUS
It is an open-air archaeological 
museum located in the heart 
of town. Its construction

(area: 150,000 m2) which

Agora. This building

Palace. It lies on the

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
The Ancient Roman Forum, located at Plateia Dikastirion, is a significant archaeological site that dates back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century AD. This area served as the social and religious center of Thessaloniki during the Roman period, covering approximately 2 hectares. The forum was constructed in two phases, with its gradual abandonment occurring after the 7th century.

Excavations have revealed a slab-paved square surrounded by arcades and public buildings, showcasing the architectural grandeur of the time. Notable structures include luxury houses adorned with exquisite mosaics, such as the residences of Epigenis and Evvoulos. The forum also housed the Sevasteio, a temple dedicated to the worship of Roman emperors, and a basilica that facilitated trade and banking transactions.

One of the most remarkable features of the forum is the double underground Cryptoporticus, a covered passageway likely used as a public storehouse. This structure highlights the advanced engineering and urban planning of the Romans, providing insight into their daily life and commerce.

The forum's layout reflects the importance of public spaces in Roman society, where citizens gathered for social, political, and economic activities. The presence of entertainment areas, shops, and worship sites indicates a vibrant community life.

Visiting the Ancient Roman Forum offers a unique opportunity to explore the remnants of Thessaloniki's rich history. The site is not only an Instagrammable spot with its impressive ruins but also a place to connect with the city's past. As a first-time visitor, you can appreciate the blend of history and culture while enjoying the local atmosphere. The forum stands as a testament to the city's significance during the Roman Empire and remains a must-see for anyone interested in ancient history.
reference: The Ancient Roman Forum was revealed during excavations at Plateia Dikastirion in 1966, which halted the construction of the Court House and other state buildings intended to create a civic center. This discovery highlights the historical significance of the site, as it reflects the urban planning and architectural practices of ancient Rome. The forum served as a central public space in Roman cities, where various activities, including political, social, and commercial events, took place.

['Following the central 
European architectural trend of

and has access to a tower. 
Prince Nicholas, the city’s first 
Greek military commander, was 
accommodated here in 1912; 
in 1916-1917 E. Venizelos 
stayed in the villa as head of 
the temporary revolutionary 
Government of National Defence. 
In 1928 the building was bought

and during the years 1938 –

3.6  Ahmet Kapanci Villa 
(105, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
It was built in 1905 by P. 
Arrigoni, as a country (seaside) 
residence for Ahmet Kapanci,  
a Jewish merchant and Mayor 
of the City. The architectural 
style is a mixed one as the 
eclectic features combine 
neoclassical, renaissance, art 
nouveau and gothic motifs.  
In 1926, the Greek State took 
ownership and since then 
the premises housed the Red 
Cross, the Gestapo, and NATO 
services until 1973.', '35

1932. There are small copper

Chalkeon.

edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two

and hot areas) and there is

6th walk: 
NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE

1.1  Monument

One of the landmarks

2nd walk:

Vlali square you will find

7.3  Bezesteni.

7.4  Stoa Saul.', '22
2nd walk:

aisled post-byzantine basilica.

6.3  The Jewish Museum

6.4  Venizelou street.

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
Eleftherios Venizelos was a prominent Greek statesman and politician, serving as Prime Minister of Greece multiple times between 1910 and 1932. He is widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in modern Greek history due to his pivotal role in shaping the country's political landscape and foreign policy during a tumultuous period.

Born in 1864 on the island of Crete, Venizelos initially became involved in the Cretan struggle for autonomy from Ottoman rule. His leadership and diplomatic skills earned him recognition, and he eventually became a key figure in the movement for Greek national unification. Venizelos was instrumental in the Balkan Wars (1912-1913), which expanded Greece's territory significantly, including the acquisition of Thessaloniki, a city that remains culturally and historically significant.

His importance extends beyond military achievements; Venizelos was a visionary reformer who advocated for modernization in Greece. He implemented various social, economic, and educational reforms aimed at improving the lives of Greek citizens. His policies laid the groundwork for Greece's development in the 20th century.

Venizelos also played a crucial role in Greece's involvement in World War I, aligning the country with the Allies and advocating for Greece's interests in the post-war negotiations. His efforts contributed to the establishment of the modern Greek state and its international standing.

In Thessaloniki, a bust of Eleftherios Venizelos stands in Plateia Dikastirion, commemorating his legacy. For visitors, this site not only offers a glimpse into his historical significance but also serves as a reminder of the city's rich cultural heritage. Exploring Thessaloniki provides an opportunity to appreciate Venizelos's contributions while enjoying the city's vibrant atmosphere and historical landmarks.
reference: Eleftherios Venizelos was a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. His bust stands in the centre of Plateia Dikastirion, which is a spacious green square in the historic centre.

response:
Paradise Baths, known for its historical significance, is a remarkable site located in Thessaloniki. This ancient bathing complex is divided into three sections: cold, tepid, and hot areas, and features a vaulted tank for heating water. It was widely recognized by the name "Paradise Baths" until 1968, reflecting its long-standing cultural importance.

Adjacent to the baths, you can find a Roman platform that indicates the ground level from 2000 years ago, providing a glimpse into the city's rich history during the Roman period. The baths are not only a place for relaxation but also a site of archaeological interest, making it an excellent spot for sightseeing.

Visiting Paradise Baths offers a unique opportunity to immerse yourself in the local culture and history. The site is ideal for photography, especially for those seeking Instagrammable spots, as the ancient architecture and serene surroundings create a picturesque backdrop. 

While exploring the area, you can also engage with locals and learn more about the historical context of the baths and their significance in Thessaloniki's past. This interaction can enhance your experience, making it more memorable and enriching.

If you're planning a weekend visit during the summer, consider including Paradise Baths in your itinerary. It provides a blend of leisure and cultural exploration, perfect for a first-time visitor looking to experience the essence of Thessaloniki.
reference: Paradise Baths, also known as Bey Hamami, is the country’s largest Ottoman bath house, built in 1444. It features a multi-domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, divided into cold, tepid, and hot areas, and includes a vaulted tank for heating water.

92), aged approx. 200,000 – 
400,000 years. Other similar 
places are the Biblical, 
Folk Art, and Criminology 
Museums, noteworthy theatre, 
Modern Greek literature and 
Education Academy archives, 
and also collections of 
manuscripts, books etc.
2.3  Observatory.
One of the finest buildings 
of the A.U.Th. complex is this 
one, constructed in 1954 to 
plans by I. Triantafyllides; its 
circular shape bears a direct 
reference to Rotunda.
3 	\x07
AGIOU DIMITRIOU 
STREET
This large road in the 
north section of the historic 
centre is one of the oldest 
in the city. There are many 
a beautiful block of flats 
dating to the Interwar Period 
in the surrounding area, that 
have survived the postwar 
increased building activities, 
particularly on Pasteur, Profitis 
Ilias and Kameniatou Streets. 
In recent decades, emigrants 
settled in Kassandrou Street 
and the neighbouring area, 
mostly coming from Eastern 
Europe, and opened shops and 
small restaurants, adding a 
multinational colour to the area.
MUST SEE:
3.1  Dioikitirio.', '18
link the town’s civic centre 
(Dikastirion Square, see p. 35) 
and Kassandrou Street with 
Aristotelous Square and the 
seafront. All along the street 
there are buildings the facades 
of which all follow specific 
architectural patterns with 
colonnades and arcades, and 
they house offices, bookshops, 
stores, hotels, state agencies, 
residencies etc. The junction of 
Aristotelous and Ermou Streets 
is the location of the church of 
Agia [Saint] Theodora (1937) 
built on an old monastery site 
now housing a community of 
monks; facing north you will 
see upper Aristotelous square.
1.2  Shopping streets
(see p. 27)
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
It starts at the harbour from 
the west and goes eastward 
to the White Tower (see p. 24) 
and it is known as Palia Paralia 
[Old Seafront]. The Turks 
opened it up in 1882, following 
an urban plan for modernising 
the city, after the seafront city 
walls were demolished. For 
many decades, traders and 
warships, fishing boats and 
yachts would dock along the 
wharf. Today, this is one of 
the top places in Thessaloniki, 
crossed daily by thousands of 
locals and visitors.', '27
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
a café as well as the eclectic-
style (military) building at the 
corner of Vas. Georgiou and 
Kaftanzoglou Streets, now 
housing the local branch  
of the Greek Scouts.
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
(see p. 16)
3 	SHOPPING STREETS
In the area including 
Proxenou Koromila and 
Mitropoleos roads and the 
adjacent streets such as 
Palaion Patron Germanou-
Vogatsikou, Chrysostomou 
Smyrnis, Mitropolitou Iosif, 
Lassani, Agias Sofias, Karolou 
Dil (lined with remarkable 
buildings of the interwar 
period) and Tsimiski street, 
you will find some of the 
most expensive shops (selling 
clothes, shoes, jewellery, 
furniture, accessories etc) as 
well as a number of the most 
well-known shopping malls 
in the city. You will also find 
haute couture boutiques by 
Greek and foreign designers 
and several art galleries. 
Thessalonians visit the area  
for their shopping as they 
go out for a coffee, a meal 
or a drink in the numerous 
hangouts lining the streets.']
reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
Kleisouras Street is not explicitly mentioned in the provided excerpts, but based on the context of Thessaloniki's historic center, it is likely to be part of the vibrant urban landscape that characterizes the area. The historic center is rich in cultural and architectural significance, featuring a blend of traditional markets, impressive buildings, and lively streets that reflect the city's diverse history.

In the vicinity of Kleisouras Street, you can explore various attractions that are ideal for a leisurely weekend visit. The area is known for its traditional markets, where you can find local products, textiles, and jewelry, providing a great opportunity to engage with local culture and meet residents. The nearby Modiano Market, built in 1922, is a must-see, featuring a glass-roofed structure filled with food shops that showcase Thessaloniki's culinary delights.

Additionally, the streets around Kleisouras likely include notable shopping areas, such as Tsimiski and Karolou Dil Streets, which are lined with boutiques and cafes. These streets are perfect for leisurely strolls, allowing you to soak in the local atmosphere while capturing Instagrammable moments with their beautiful architecture and vibrant street life.

The historic center also features significant landmarks like Aristotelous Square and the White Tower, both of which are easily accessible and provide excellent opportunities for sightseeing. The blend of modern and historical elements in this area makes it an exciting place for first-time visitors.

Overall, while Kleisouras Street may not be highlighted, its significance lies in its connection to the broader historic center, offering a rich tapestry of experiences that cater to your interests in sightseeing, local interaction, and cultural immersion.
reference: Kleisouras Streets is located adjacent to the Court House square, known as Plateia Dikastirion, in the historic center. This area features small copper workshops that have been part of the local tradition since the Byzantine period, highlighting the street's historical significance and ongoing craftsmanship.

Main street.

street used to cross the town

Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals,

Roman Forum.

1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of the archaeological site is 
covered by a large rectangular 
square [Α] with traces of 
marble paving. In the S section 
of the square lies the largest 
part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public 
storehouse.', '29
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
8 	\x07PALACE OF GALERIUS
It is an open-air archaeological 
museum located in the heart 
of town. Its construction  
began in the late 3rd – early  
4th c. by Galerius and is part  
of the Galerian Complex 
(area: 150,000 m2) which 
included the Hippodrome,  
the Arch or Kamara (see p.  
37) and Rotunda (see p. 10),  
as well as other buildings 
to suit various purposes, 
now situated under modern 
structures. Until its destruction 
in the 7th c., other emperors 
stayed here besides Galerius, 
(such as Theodosios I and 
others). It is considered as one 
of the major monuments of 
the Late Antiquity, nationwide. 
MUST SEE:
8.1  Octagon.
This was a throne and 
audience hall with a double-
apsed anteroom and an 
octagonal shape. It boasts an 
exceptional interior decoration 
and elaborate floors. It used 
to communicate with the sea 
via a propylaeum and a large 
peristyle, part of which is the 
impressive marble decorative 
arch with Galerius’ bust on 
display at the Archaeological 
Museum (see p. 70). 
8.2  Colonnaded yard.
There were rooms on 
its three sides. Stoas with 
tessellated floors isolated 
the atrium from other 
constructions.', '83
DAY EXCURSIONS
Agora. This building 
complex dates to the 4th c. 
BC; it occupied a 70,000 m2  
area and used to be the 
administrative, commercial, 
cultural and artistic hub of 
the town. In the centre there 
was a large court surrounded 
by arcades and rooms where 
all kinds of commercial shops 
and workshops, as well as  
the Public Archives were  
to be found. 
Temples. Excavations  
have unearthed the Temple  
of the Mother of Gods and  
of Aphrodite (4th c. BC),  
the Temple of Darron (2nd c. 
BC) and the round-shaped 
Thesmoforio, a name given  
to temples dedicated to 
goddess Demeter; it is located 
in the modern town area.
Palace. It lies on the 
northernmost hill and covers 
a 60,000 m2 area. You will 
reach it via the modern town. 
The earlier buildings date to 
the 2nd half of the 4th c. BC; 
complementary constructions 
were added later. In the 
centre there was a peristyle 
surrounding the courtyard, 
a propylaeum, and the royal 
quarters were on the north side.
Eastern cemetery. It is 
located east of the town.']

response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century AD, served as a vital social and religious center for the city during ancient times. This expansive area, covering approximately 2 hectares, was designed as a hub for public life, commerce, and governance.

The Forum featured a slab-paved square surrounded by arcades and various public buildings, making it a focal point for community gatherings and activities. On the western side, luxury houses adorned with exquisite mosaics were situated, indicating the wealth and status of their inhabitants. Among these was the temple dedicated to the worship of Roman emperors, highlighting the Forum's role in religious practices.

In addition to its residential and religious functions, the Forum also included areas designated for trade and banking transactions, facilitating economic activities within the city. The presence of the Roman basilica further underscores its importance as a center for public affairs and legal matters.

The archaeological site also revealed significant structures such as the Monument of the Shields, which featured depictions of shields and cuirasses, and the Forum Thermae, a complex of public baths that catered to the social needs of the citizens. These facilities were not only places for hygiene but also served as venues for social interaction and leisure.

Overall, the Roman Forum was a multifaceted space that encapsulated the civic, commercial, and cultural life of Thessaloniki during the Roman period, making it an essential part of the city's historical landscape.
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city. It was constructed in two phases, completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

['71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.', '36
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the

was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the

[D] was unearthed which has

ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '90
DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum 
Thermae.
Polygonal building.', '8
 315 BC:	
26 adjoining townlets 
merge to form Thessaloniki. 
The town is founded by 
Cassander, King of Macedonia, 
and named after his wife 
Thessaloniki – half sister  
to Alexander the Great.
 168 BC:	
The Romans take the city 
over.
 148 BC:	
It becomes the capital  
town of the roman province 
of Macedonia.
 130 BC:	
Construction of Via Egnatia 
which connected the town 
with the then known world.
 circa 50 BC:	
Cicero, the Roman orator 
becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians.']

response:
Macedonia holds significant historical importance in relation to the Roman Forum, particularly as a key region during the Roman Empire. The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century AD, served as a central hub for public life, commerce, and governance in the city, which was the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia. This forum was not just a marketplace; it was a vibrant social and political center where citizens engaged in trade, cultural events, and civic activities.

The archaeological site reveals a well-planned urban layout, featuring a slab-paved square surrounded by arcades and public buildings. Notable structures included luxury houses adorned with exquisite mosaics, a temple dedicated to the worship of Roman emperors, and a basilica that facilitated trade and banking transactions. The presence of the forum underscores the integration of local Macedonian culture with Roman administrative practices, showcasing how the region adapted to and thrived under Roman rule.

Additionally, the Roman Forum is linked to the broader historical narrative of Macedonia, which was pivotal in the Hellenistic period and later became a vital part of the Roman Empire. The city of Thessaloniki itself was founded in 315 BC by Cassander, a general of Alexander the Great, and evolved into a significant urban center by the time of Roman conquest in 168 BC. The forum's existence reflects the continuity of urban life from the Hellenistic era through to Late Antiquity, illustrating the region's enduring legacy.

Visiting the Roman Forum allows one to appreciate the architectural and cultural achievements of Macedonia during Roman times, making it a must-see for anyone interested in the historical interplay between local and imperial influences.
reference: During the Roman period, Macedonia was home to a 2-hectare area that served as the social and religious center of the city, known as the Roman Forum. This site was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

response:
The Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant for several reasons, particularly in the context of Thessaloniki's rich historical and cultural tapestry. This mural reflects the transition of the site from a pagan to a Christian space, illustrating the broader religious and cultural shifts that occurred during Late Antiquity.

Originally, the Roman Forum served as a bustling center of civic life, showcasing the grandeur of Roman architecture and public life. However, as Christianity began to spread, many such sites were repurposed to accommodate the new faith. The mural represents this transformation, symbolizing the integration of Christian beliefs into the fabric of a city that was once predominantly pagan.

Moreover, the mural's artistic style and iconography provide valuable insights into the early Christian community in Thessaloniki. It showcases the unique blend of Roman artistic techniques with emerging Christian themes, highlighting the cultural syncretism of the period. This melding of styles not only reflects the local adaptation of Christian art but also serves as a testament to the resilience and creativity of the community during a time of significant change.

The mural also holds spiritual significance, as it is associated with the early Christian martyrs and saints, linking the site to the broader narrative of Christian martyrdom in the region. This connection enhances the site's importance as a place of worship and remembrance, drawing visitors who seek to understand the historical context of their faith.

In summary, the Christian mural in the Roman Forum is significant as it embodies the transition from paganism to Christianity, showcases the artistic evolution of the period, and connects to the spiritual heritage of Thessaloniki. It serves as a poignant reminder of the city's historical journey and its role in the development of early Christian culture.
reference: The Christian mural uncovered in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents an early example of Christian art, highlighting the transition of the site from a social and religious center of the Roman period to one that incorporated Christian elements. This mural was found on one of the walls of the double underground Cryptoporticus, which was likely used as a public storehouse.

response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period. This expansive area, covering approximately 2 hectares, was constructed in two main phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and remained in use until its gradual abandonment after the 7th century.

The Forum featured a large rectangular square that was likely paved with marble, surrounded by various public buildings and arcades. It was a bustling hub for trade, cultural events, and religious activities. Notable structures within the Forum included a Roman basilica, areas designated for banking transactions, and the Monument of the Shields, which showcased intricate depictions of shields and cuirasses.

In addition to its commercial significance, the Forum housed the Temple of Sevasteio, dedicated to the worship of Roman emperors, and the Odeon, a venue for cultural performances. The site also contained the “Enchanted Ones” (las Incantadas), a two-storeyed colonnaded archway adorned with Corinthian columns, which added to its architectural grandeur.

Archaeological excavations have revealed various artifacts, including mosaic floors, marble stairs, and remnants of a colonnade, providing insight into the daily life and social interactions of the people who frequented this vibrant space. The Forum was not only a place for commerce and worship but also a gathering point for the community, reflecting the cultural and social dynamics of Thessaloniki during the Roman era. 

Visiting the Roman Forum today offers a glimpse into the city's rich history and serves as an Instagrammable spot, perfect for capturing the essence of ancient Thessaloniki.
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city.

4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
1970. It combines elements 
of modern and traditional 
Macedonian architecture with 
references to the style of the 
Mount Athos monasteries.
1.9  Acheiropoiitos church.
(see p. 9) 
1.10 Agios [Saint] 
Athanasios church.
This timber-roofed church  
is located in the SE side  
of Acheiropoiitos church.  
It was built in 1818 as a three-
aisled basilica and until 1880 
there were ruins of an ancient 
structure in the churchyard.  
It is now a parish church.
1.11 Nedelkou Building.
(109, Egnatia st.). This 1909 
building is a two-storeyed 
piece of fine architecture (Xen. 
Paionidis). In the past, the 
ground floor housed shops 
and the 1st floor was the 
house of the Nedelkou family. 
It combines renaissance, 
baroque, neoclassical and art-
nouveau elements and has an 
interesting interior decoration. 
Today it houses the Mount 
Athos Centre where the stay 
permits are issued to those 
who wish to visit the Mount 
Athos monasteries (see p. 92); 
there is also a bookshop and 
an exhibition area.
1.12 Galerius Arch (Kamara).
One of the town’s major 
landmarks, this arch is  
the usual rendezvous place  
for locals.', '39
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
Museum houses exhibits  
of human skulls, known 
worldwide to have been found 
in the area of Axios river 
(aged 9.5 million years) and 
in the Petralona Cave (see p. 
92), aged approx. 200,000 – 
400,000 years. Other similar 
places are the Biblical, 
Folk Art, and Criminology 
Museums, noteworthy theatre, 
Modern Greek literature and 
Education Academy archives, 
and also collections of 
manuscripts, books etc.
2.3  Observatory.
One of the finest buildings 
of the A.U.Th. complex is this 
one, constructed in 1954 to 
plans by I. Triantafyllides; its 
circular shape bears a direct 
reference to Rotunda.
3 	\x07
AGIOU DIMITRIOU 
STREET
This large road in the 
north section of the historic 
centre is one of the oldest 
in the city. There are many 
a beautiful block of flats 
dating to the Interwar Period 
in the surrounding area, that 
have survived the postwar 
increased building activities, 
particularly on Pasteur, Profitis 
Ilias and Kameniatou Streets. 
In recent decades, emigrants 
settled in Kassandrou Street 
and the neighbouring area, 
mostly coming from Eastern 
Europe, and opened shops and 
small restaurants, adding a 
multinational colour to the area.
MUST SEE:
3.1  Dioikitirio.', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the

An impressive Macedonian

Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

2nd walk:

TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
Vlali square you will find 
coffee shops and traditional 
restaurants. A memorial has 
been erected at the junction 
of Spandoni, Ermou and 
Venizelou streets, in memory 
of MP Gr. Lamprakis who was

In Vatikioti market as well

of Aristotelous street, there 
are shops selling produce, 
spices, songbirds, packaging 
and shoe-making ware; in 
Athonos square you will find 
workshops selling wooden and 
wicker chairs as well as many 
tavernas and ouzo restaurants. 
7.3  Bezesteni.
It lies at the corner of 
Solomou and Venizelou 
streets. It is a rectangular 
building with four entrances 
and six lead-covered domes 
with inscriptions of all of 
the craftsmen’s names on 
them. It was built in the late 
15th – early 16th c. as a textile 
market [bezesten] and a 
market of precious stones, 
which was guarded 24 hours 
a day. It has kept most of its 
character as there are over 
110 shops in the interior as 
well as in the exterior – most 
of them selling textiles or 
jewellery.

flats facing the adjacent

reference_contexts: ["42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Agios Athanasios is a charming area in Thessaloniki that offers a blend of historical significance and local culture, making it an ideal spot for a solo traveler seeking authentic experiences. The Agios Athanasios church, located on the southeastern side of the Acheiropoiitos church, is a notable landmark. Built in 1818, this three-aisled basilica features a timber roof and is surrounded by remnants of ancient structures, adding to its historical allure.

The neighborhood is characterized by its traditional architecture and vibrant atmosphere. As you stroll through the streets, you'll encounter quaint shops, local tavernas, and cafes where you can enjoy authentic Greek cuisine. The area is also known for its friendly locals, providing ample opportunities for interaction and cultural exchange.

For those interested in history, the nearby archaeological sites, including ancient tombs and a Neolithic settlement, offer a glimpse into the region's rich past. The impressive Macedonian tomb unearthed in Agios Athanasios is particularly noteworthy for history enthusiasts.

Accessibility is convenient, with bus lines connecting the area to the city center, making it easy to explore other attractions in Thessaloniki. The neighborhood's picturesque streets are perfect for capturing Instagrammable moments, especially during the summer when the vibrant colors of the buildings and the lively atmosphere come to life.

Overall, Agios Athanasios is a delightful destination that combines sightseeing with local culture, making it a must-visit for anyone looking to experience the essence of Thessaloniki. Whether you're visiting the church, enjoying a meal at a local taverna, or exploring the historical sites, you'll find plenty to appreciate in this charming area.
reference: AG. ATHANASIOS is one of the many churches located in Thessaloniki’s Old Town, an area rich in atmosphere and history. The Old Town has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. The area has narrow alleys and scant squares, preserving its original town planning and architectural features.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.

Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians. 
The town is spared destruction 
thanks to its massive walls.

The Norsemen occupy 
Thessaloniki.

After the 20-year Frankish 
domination of Thessaloniki, 
the town is taken by Theodore

declared the capital of the 
Despotate of Epirus.
 1300-1430:	
The golden age of the 
town involves great financial, 
social and intellectual growth. 
Some of the most significant 
monuments, built at that time, 
still stand today.
 1342-1349:	
The Zealot Movement 
prevails as a reaction to 
medieval hegemonism  
and the reign “by the grace  
of God”.
 1423:	
The town surrenders to the 
Venetians.

The Ottoman Turks seize 
Thessaloniki.

A large Jewish population
