['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.']

response:
Kalamaria, a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, offers a delightful blend of coastal charm and local culture, making it an appealing destination for leisure travelers. Here are some notable features and attractions that enhance its appeal:

1. **Seafront Promenade**: The waterfront along N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, perfect for enjoying local cuisine while soaking in the sea views. This lively atmosphere is ideal for socializing and capturing Instagram-worthy moments.

2. **Aretsou-Krini Beach**: This popular beach area features a marina, open-air cinema, and various marine sports facilities. The beach is a great spot for relaxation and enjoying summer activities, making it a must-visit for sun-seekers.

3. **Komninon Street**: Known for its pedestrian-friendly layout, this street is filled with shops, cafés, and restaurants. It leads to the central square, where you can find the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, both of which are significant local landmarks.

4. **Cultural Heritage**: Kalamaria has a rich history, with remnants of its past visible in the traditional architecture and the refugee houses that still stand. Exploring these areas provides insight into the local culture and history.

5. **Accessibility**: The area is well-connected by public transport, with bus lines that make it easy to navigate and explore other parts of Thessaloniki. This accessibility is beneficial for first-time visitors looking to maximize their experience.

6. **Local Interaction**: The friendly locals and the familiar Greek culture create an inviting atmosphere for travelers. Engaging with residents can enhance your experience, offering opportunities to learn about local traditions and hidden gems.

In summary, Kalamaria's combination of scenic waterfronts, cultural landmarks, and vibrant local life makes it an attractive destination for those seeking a memorable weekend getaway.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square, making it easy for travelers to explore these attractions.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful waterfront and lively atmosphere. Here are some popular areas to explore:

1. **Aretsou-Krini**: This area stretches along the seafront and features the only marina in town, which has a 242-berth capacity. You can enjoy the local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a variety of café-bars and fish tavernas along N. Plastira Street. This waterfront street is particularly lively and perfect for leisurely strolls and dining.

2. **Komninon Street**: This pedestrian-only street is the longest part of the town’s main thoroughfare. It is lined with shops, cafés, small bars, and restaurants. The central square here is home to the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, making it a cultural hub worth visiting.

**Getting There**: 

To reach Kalamaria, you can take bus lines 5 or 5A from Eleftherias Square. These buses will take you to the Aretsou area, where you can easily explore the waterfront and nearby attractions. If you prefer to visit Komninon Street, you can get off at the Naftikos Omilos (Marine Club) stop or the Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou.

Kalamaria is an excellent choice for a weekend getaway, especially in the summer when the area is bustling with activity. The combination of scenic views, local cuisine, and cultural sites makes it an ideal spot for sightseeing and enjoying the local atmosphere. Don't forget to capture the picturesque waterfront and vibrant street life for your Instagram feed!
reference: Some popular areas in Kalamaria include Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas. To get to these areas, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square and get off at the Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

user_input: What are the key attractions and features of Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.', 'MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).
Situated on cape Mikro 
Emvolo or Karampournaki, 
Little Palace was built in the 
1950’s and used to be the 
country residence of the greek 
royal family; today the minister 
of Macedonia-Thrace and 
the President of the Hellenic 
Republic stay here when 
visiting the city. The ground 
floor includes the lounges,  
a dance hall and an atrium;  
the first floor includes two 
suites and secondary rooms. 
It is surrounded by a garden 
and it affords an amazing 
view of the city as well as Mts 
Chortiatis and Olympus.
2.3  Kodra former military 
camp.
Building works are under way 
to change it into a park. The 
Municipality of Kalamaria often 
hosts cultural events and visual 
art exhibitions there. On-site 
excavations brought to light a 
settlement dating to the archaic 
and classical times (9th – 5th 
c. BC), which some scientists 
believe it is identified as the 
location of Ancient Thermi.
71.  
Kyverneio 
(Palataki) 
overlooks cape 
Karampournaki 
(Kalamaria).
72.  
Panorama 
area offers a 
fine view of 
the city and its 
environs.
71', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.']

response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront along N. Plastira Street, which is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. The area features the popular Aretsou-Krini beach, a marina, and an open-air cinema, perfect for leisure activities. The pedestrian-only Komninon Street is the heart of Kalamaria, where visitors can explore shops, cafés, and restaurants, and visit the central square housing the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible, with bus lines connecting to the city center.

In contrast, Panorama is situated 12 km south of Thessaloniki, built on the slopes of Mt. Chortiatis, offering stunning panoramic views of the city. This suburb is characterized by luxury villas and green spaces, providing a more tranquil atmosphere compared to the bustling Kalamaria. While it lacks the same level of commercial activity, Panorama features a small shopping area and is known for its natural beauty, including Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a café and a small zoo. The area is ideal for those seeking relaxation and scenic walks, with paths leading to an artificial lake.

Both suburbs have their unique charm: Kalamaria is perfect for socializing and enjoying local cuisine, while Panorama offers a serene escape with breathtaking views. For a first-time visitor, Kalamaria provides a lively atmosphere with plenty of Instagrammable spots, while Panorama is suited for those looking to unwind in nature. Depending on your preference for activity or relaxation, either suburb can offer a fulfilling experience during a weekend stay in Thessaloniki.
reference:
Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a popular destination year-round. The main street, Komninon, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square.

In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It was uninhabited until the early 20th century, with its first inhabitants being refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Panorama is also known for its natural attractions, such as Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way. Both areas provide unique experiences, with Kalamaria focusing on coastal activities and nightlife, while Panorama emphasizes residential luxury and natural beauty.

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria, a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, offers a mix of attractions and facilities perfect for a weekend getaway. The area is known for its beautiful waterfront, lined with café-bars and fish tavernas along N. Plastira Street, making it an ideal spot for leisurely strolls and dining. 

Key attractions include:

1. **Aretsou-Krini Beach**: This popular beach features a marine sports club and an open-air cinema, perfect for relaxation and entertainment. The beach is well-maintained and offers a lively atmosphere.

2. **Komninon Street**: A pedestrian-only street filled with shops, cafés, and restaurants. Here, you can visit the central square, which houses the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, both notable landmarks.

3. **Kyverneio (Little Palace)**: Located on cape Mikro Emvolo, this former royal residence offers stunning views of the city and surrounding mountains. It’s a great spot for photography enthusiasts.

4. **Kodra Former Military Camp**: Currently being transformed into a park, this site hosts cultural events and exhibitions, providing insight into the local history.

To access these attractions, you can use public transportation. Bus lines 5 and 5A connect you to the seafront area, with stops at Naftikos Omilos (Marine Club) and Chamodrakas in Aretsou. For those traveling from Thessaloniki city center, buses to Kalamaria are frequent and budget-friendly.

For a more immersive experience, consider visiting local tavernas and engaging with residents, as many locals are friendly and willing to share their culture. With its picturesque settings and accessible facilities, Kalamaria is an excellent choice for a leisurely summer weekend.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. To access these areas, bus lines 5 and 5A depart from Eleftherias square, with stops at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] or Chamodrakas in the Aretsou area.

GOLF
You will find an 18-hole

SKI CENTRES
Thessaloniki is relatively close 
to some of the best known ski 
centres in Northern Greece, 
and offers the opportunity for 
a day trip to any of them. Here 
is a list:
Seli Ski Centre.
It is located at a 1,500-2,000 
m. elevation, there are 16 runs 
(total length: 15 km), 11 lifts 
and two chalets. Chryso Elafi 
(meaning Golden Deer) is a 
private ski centre situated 95 
km NW of Thessaloniki  
(24 km NW of Veroia town). 
Information: 
tel.: 23310 26.237 
website: www.seli-ski.gr
Elatochori Ski Centre.
It lies 8 km W of Elatochori 
village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8 
runs (total length: 9 km), 5 
lifts, shops renting or selling

BEACHES

4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist

an important history, bustling

south of Thessaloniki,

in Kassandra and Sithonia for

the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic

encompasses 20 -presently

How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get

Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA

At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

response:
Chalkidiki, known for its stunning beaches and vibrant atmosphere, is a fantastic destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is one of the most frequented areas by locals and tourists alike. Beaches like **Sani Beach** and **Kalithea Beach** are renowned for their crystal-clear waters and lively beach bars. Kassandra is approximately 80 km from Thessaloniki, making it easily accessible for a day trip.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque beaches, Sithonia offers spots like **Vourvourou** and **Kavourotripes** (also known as Orange Beach). These beaches are famous for their stunning scenery and are about 100 km from Thessaloniki.

3. **Agios Nikolaos**: Located on the Sithonia Peninsula, this beach is perfect for those seeking a quieter experience. It features beautiful waters and is around 90 km from Thessaloniki.

4. **Neos Marmaras**: This beach town is popular for its vibrant nightlife and beautiful beaches, such as **Paradisos Beach**. It is approximately 110 km from Thessaloniki.

5. **Halkidiki Beaches**: The beaches in the Halkidiki region, including **Kallithea** and **Pefkochori**, are well-known for their lively atmosphere and are about 90 km from Thessaloniki.

These beaches not only offer stunning views and opportunities for relaxation but also provide a chance to interact with locals and experience the vibrant culture of the region. Whether you prefer the bustling atmosphere of Kassandra or the serene beauty of Sithonia, Chalkidiki has something for every beach lover.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their stunning scenery and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

How to get there. From

6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the

unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105

A bit farther away, you can try the

GOLF
You will find an 18-hole

of the Porto Carras Grand

SKI CENTRES
Thessaloniki is relatively close 
to some of the best known ski 
centres in Northern Greece, 
and offers the opportunity for 
a day trip to any of them. Here 
is a list:
Seli Ski Centre.
It is located at a 1,500-2,000 
m. elevation, there are 16 runs 
(total length: 15 km), 11 lifts 
and two chalets. Chryso Elafi 
(meaning Golden Deer) is a

km NW of Thessaloniki

Elatochori Ski Centre.
It lies 8 km W of Elatochori 
village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8 
runs (total length: 9 km), 5 
lifts, shops renting or selling 
equipment and a chalet.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the

(tools, animal bones etc) are

and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the

a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.

lovely beaches.

DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short

for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.']

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Chalkidiki, a popular destination for beach lovers, offers several stunning beaches that are perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some of the most popular beaches you can visit:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: Known for its vibrant nightlife and beautiful sandy beaches, Kassandra is a favorite among young travelers. Notable beaches include:
   - **Sani Beach**: Approximately 70 km from Thessaloniki, this beach is famous for its clear waters and luxurious resorts.
   - **Kalithea Beach**: About 80 km away, it features a lively atmosphere with plenty of bars and restaurants.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: This area is renowned for its picturesque landscapes and tranquil beaches. Key spots include:
   - **Vourvourou Beach**: Located around 100 km from Thessaloniki, it offers stunning views and crystal-clear waters, ideal for swimming and relaxation.
   - **Kavourotripes Beach**: Approximately 110 km away, this hidden gem is known for its unique rock formations and serene environment.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, it also has beautiful beaches:
   - **Ouranoupoli Beach**: About 120 km from Thessaloniki, this beach provides a scenic view of Mount Athos and is perfect for a peaceful day by the sea.

Traveling to these beaches is convenient, with options for public transport or car rentals available from Thessaloniki. Each beach offers a unique experience, from lively atmospheres to serene settings, making them ideal for a summer weekend escape. Don’t forget to capture the stunning views for your Instagram feed!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their scenic beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

It is located in the

GOLF
You will find an 18-hole

SKI CENTRES
Thessaloniki is relatively close 
to some of the best known ski 
centres in Northern Greece, 
and offers the opportunity for 
a day trip to any of them. Here 
is a list:
Seli Ski Centre.
It is located at a 1,500-2,000 
m. elevation, there are 16 runs 
(total length: 15 km), 11 lifts 
and two chalets. Chryso Elafi 
(meaning Golden Deer) is a 
private ski centre situated 95 
km NW of Thessaloniki  
(24 km NW of Veroia town). 
Information: 
tel.: 23310 26.237 
website: www.seli-ski.gr
Elatochori Ski Centre.
It lies 8 km W of Elatochori 
village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8 
runs (total length: 9 km), 5 
lifts, shops renting or selling 
equipment and a chalet.', '105

BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see

A bit farther away, you can try the

At a 60 – 90 min. distance from

MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS

4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.

numerous 
lovely beaches.

DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.']

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. AINOU SQ. KAOUDI SQ. PATRIKIOU AILIDI SQ. SQ. SKRA SQ. PILEA KALAMARIA THESSALONIKI KERAMEIA ALATINI ARISTOTELIS AGIOU ELEFTHERIOU SQ. RETIREMENT HOME 2.2 2.3 2.4 2.5 2.1 2.4 72']
response:
Chalkidiki, known for its stunning beaches and vibrant atmosphere, is a fantastic destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is one of the most frequented areas by locals and tourists alike. Beaches like **Sani Beach** and **Kalithea** are renowned for their crystal-clear waters and lively beach bars. Kassandra is approximately 80 km from Thessaloniki, making it easily accessible by car or bus.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque beaches, Sithonia offers spots like **Vourvourou** and **Kavourotripes** (also known as Orange Beach). These beaches are famous for their stunning landscapes and clear waters. Sithonia is about 100 km from Thessaloniki.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, Athos also boasts beautiful beaches. **Ouranoupoli** is a popular choice, offering a mix of relaxation and cultural experiences. Athos is roughly 120 km from Thessaloniki.

4. **Halkidiki Beaches**: In addition to the peninsulas, beaches like **Nea Potidea** and **Nea Moudania** are closer options, located about 60 km from Thessaloniki. These beaches provide a mix of local charm and beautiful scenery.

Traveling to these beaches is convenient, with various transportation options available, including buses and rental cars. The journey typically takes between 1 to 2 hours, depending on the destination. 

In summer, these beaches are perfect for sunbathing, swimming, and enjoying local cuisine at nearby tavernas. Be sure to capture the picturesque views for your Instagram feed, as Chalkidiki is filled with stunning landscapes and vibrant sunsets.
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beautiful beaches are well-known for their scenic views and are a great destination for swimming.

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is renowned for its stunning beaches, making it a perfect destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches that are easily accessible:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is one of the most visited areas in Halkidiki, known for its vibrant beach resorts and lively atmosphere. Beaches like **Sani Beach** and **Kalithea** offer beautiful sandy shores and clear waters, ideal for sunbathing and swimming. Kassandra is about a 1-1.5 hour drive from Thessaloniki.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque beaches, Sithonia features stunning spots like **Vourvourou** and **Kavourotripes**. Vourvourou is famous for its turquoise waters and scenic views, while Kavourotripes is known for its unique rock formations and secluded coves. Sithonia is approximately a 1.5-2 hour drive from Thessaloniki.

3. **Neos Marmaras**: This charming village on Sithonia offers access to beautiful beaches such as **Paradisos Beach** and **Lagomandra Beach**. Both are known for their soft sands and crystal-clear waters, perfect for relaxation and swimming. Neos Marmaras is about a 2-hour drive from Thessaloniki.

4. **Halkidiki’s Blue Flag Beaches**: Many beaches in Halkidiki, including those in Asprovalta and Nea Vrasna, have been awarded the Blue Flag for cleanliness and facilities. These beaches are family-friendly and provide various amenities, making them great for a budget-friendly day out.

To reach these beaches, you can take a bus from Thessaloniki or drive, as the roads are well-maintained and signposted. Whether you prefer the lively atmosphere of Kassandra or the serene beauty of Sithonia, Halkidiki offers a variety of beach experiences that cater to all preferences. Enjoy your summer getaway!
reference: Some popular beaches in Halkidiki that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a 60 to 90-minute distance from the city. Specific beaches mentioned are in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros.

The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Chalkidiki is renowned for its stunning beaches, making it a perfect destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches you should consider visiting:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is one of the most popular areas in Chalkidiki, known for its vibrant nightlife and beautiful beaches. Notable beaches include:
   - **Sani Beach**: Approximately 70 km from Thessaloniki, it offers crystal-clear waters and luxurious amenities.
   - **Kalithea Beach**: About 80 km away, this beach is famous for its lively atmosphere and beach bars.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque settings, Sithonia features:
   - **Vourvourou Beach**: Roughly 100 km from Thessaloniki, it boasts stunning views and shallow waters, ideal for swimming.
   - **Kavourotripes Beach**: Located about 110 km away, this hidden gem is famous for its unique rock formations and clear waters, perfect for photography.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, it also has beautiful beaches:
   - **Ouranoupoli Beach**: Approximately 120 km from Thessaloniki, this beach offers a serene environment with views of Mount Athos.

Traveling to these beaches is convenient, with options for public transport or car rentals available in Thessaloniki. The drive typically takes between 60 to 120 minutes, depending on the beach you choose. 

In summer, these beaches are not only great for swimming but also provide numerous opportunities for social media-worthy photos, thanks to their stunning landscapes and vibrant atmospheres. Enjoy your beach-hopping adventure in Chalkidiki!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

and Volvi; the place is a

makes this cave one of the

(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the

4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.

numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.

Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.

swimming pool and other

You will find an 18-hole

of the Porto Carras Grand

Seli Ski Centre.

(meaning Golden Deer) is a 
private ski centre situated 95 
km NW of Thessaloniki  
(24 km NW of Veroia town).

Elatochori Ski Centre.

village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is renowned for its stunning beaches, making it a perfect destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This peninsula is famous for its vibrant beach resorts and lively atmosphere. Beaches like **Sani Beach** and **Kalithea Beach** are particularly popular, offering crystal-clear waters and plenty of amenities. Kassandra is approximately 80 km from Thessaloniki, making it easily accessible by car or bus.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque beaches, Sithonia features stunning spots like **Vourvourou** and **Kavourotripes** (also known as Orange Beach). These beaches are famous for their natural beauty and are about 100 km from Thessaloniki.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While Mount Athos is primarily known for its monasteries, the surrounding beaches, such as **Ouranoupoli Beach**, offer beautiful views and a serene atmosphere. This area is around 120 km from Thessaloniki.

4. **Agia Triada Beach**: Closer to Thessaloniki, Agia Triada Beach is about 30 km away and is a great option for a quick beach day. It features sandy shores and is popular among locals.

5. **Peraia Beach**: Located approximately 20 km from Thessaloniki, Peraia Beach is easily accessible and offers a lively beach scene with numerous cafes and restaurants.

These beaches not only provide beautiful settings for relaxation and swimming but also offer opportunities for local interaction and cultural experiences. Whether you prefer the bustling atmosphere of Kassandra or the serene beauty of Sithonia, Halkidiki's beaches are sure to provide memorable moments perfect for sharing on social media.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

gulf. You will find a marine

response:
Chalkidiki, located south of Thessaloniki, is renowned for its stunning beaches and vibrant atmosphere, making it a perfect destination for a weekend getaway. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This peninsula is famous for its lively beaches and nightlife. Notable beaches include:
   - **Sani Beach**: Known for its crystal-clear waters and luxurious resorts, it's about 70 km from Thessaloniki.
   - **Kalithea Beach**: A popular spot with a vibrant atmosphere, located approximately 80 km from the city.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Offers a more tranquil experience with beautiful, less crowded beaches. Highlights include:
   - **Vourvourou Beach**: Renowned for its picturesque scenery and shallow waters, it's around 100 km from Thessaloniki.
   - **Kavourotripes Beach**: Famous for its unique rock formations and clear waters, this beach is about 110 km away.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, it also features beautiful beaches. 
   - **Ouranoupoli Beach**: A charming beach with views of Mount Athos, located roughly 120 km from Thessaloniki.

Traveling to these beaches is convenient, with options for public transport or car rentals. The journey typically takes between 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on traffic and your chosen destination. 

In summer, these beaches are not only perfect for sunbathing and swimming but also offer opportunities for local interactions and exploring traditional tavernas. Be sure to capture the stunning landscapes and vibrant sunsets, which are highly Instagrammable! Enjoy your beach adventure in Chalkidiki!
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach

the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for

swimming pool and other

GOLF
You will find an 18-hole 
golf course in the facilities 
of the Porto Carras Grand 
Resort, 120 km SE of 
Thessaloniki. It is one of the 
best in the country and meets

beginners or experienced

Information:

website: www.portocarras.com
SKI CENTRES
Thessaloniki is relatively close 
to some of the best known ski 
centres in Northern Greece, 
and offers the opportunity for 
a day trip to any of them. Here 
is a list:
Seli Ski Centre.
It is located at a 1,500-2,000 
m. elevation, there are 16 runs 
(total length: 15 km), 11 lifts 
and two chalets. Chryso Elafi 
(meaning Golden Deer) is a 
private ski centre situated 95 
km NW of Thessaloniki  
(24 km NW of Veroia town). 
Information: 
tel.: 23310 26.237 
website: www.seli-ski.gr
Elatochori Ski Centre.
It lies 8 km W of Elatochori 
village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8 
runs (total length: 9 km), 5 
lifts, shops renting or selling 
equipment and a chalet.']

response:
Halkidiki is renowned for its stunning beaches, making it a perfect destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is one of the most popular areas in Halkidiki, known for its vibrant nightlife and beautiful beaches. Notable beaches include:
   - **Sani Beach**: Approximately 70 km from Thessaloniki, it offers crystal-clear waters and luxurious amenities.
   - **Kalithea Beach**: About 80 km away, it's famous for its lively atmosphere and beach bars.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Known for its more tranquil and picturesque beaches, Sithonia is ideal for those seeking relaxation.
   - **Vourvourou Beach**: Located around 100 km from Thessaloniki, it features stunning turquoise waters and is great for swimming and water sports.
   - **Kavourotripes Beach**: Approximately 110 km away, this beach is famous for its unique rock formations and clear waters, perfect for photography.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, it also has beautiful beaches.
   - **Ouranoupoli Beach**: About 120 km from Thessaloniki, it offers a serene environment with stunning views of Mount Athos.

Traveling to these beaches is convenient, with options for public transport or car rentals available in Thessaloniki. The journey typically takes between 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on traffic and the specific beach destination. 

In summer, these beaches are particularly inviting, providing opportunities for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying local cuisine at nearby tavernas. Each beach offers unique charm and beauty, making them perfect for capturing Instagrammable moments while immersing yourself in the local culture.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

user_input: What are some notable beaches in Halkidiki that travelers can visit, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?

['95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '111
swimming pool and other 
Town sports grounds as well 
as on sporting events held in 
Thessaloniki.
GOLF
You will find an 18-hole 
golf course in the facilities 
of the Porto Carras Grand 
Resort, 120 km SE of 
Thessaloniki. It is one of the 
best in the country and meets 
international standards. In the 
hotel grounds you can follow 
private or group courses for 
beginners or experienced 
players.  
Information: 
tel.: 23750 77.000 
website: www.portocarras.com
SKI CENTRES
Thessaloniki is relatively close 
to some of the best known ski 
centres in Northern Greece, 
and offers the opportunity for 
a day trip to any of them. Here 
is a list:
Seli Ski Centre.
It is located at a 1,500-2,000 
m. elevation, there are 16 runs 
(total length: 15 km), 11 lifts 
and two chalets. Chryso Elafi 
(meaning Golden Deer) is a 
private ski centre situated 95 
km NW of Thessaloniki  
(24 km NW of Veroia town). 
Information: 
tel.: 23310 26.237 
website: www.seli-ski.gr
Elatochori Ski Centre.
It lies 8 km W of Elatochori 
village at a 1,400-1,900 
m. elevation. There are 8 
runs (total length: 9 km), 5 
lifts, shops renting or selling 
equipment and a chalet.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi.
